contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Magazine | title = Interview | image_file = Interview (magazine cover).jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | image_alt= | frequency = Monthly | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | total_circulation = | circulation_year = | company = [[Peter M. Brant#Brant Publications, Inc.|Brant Publications]] | issn=0149-8932 | language = English | category = Pop Culture | editors = [[Fabien Baron]] | founder =[[Andy Warhol]] | president = Dan Ragone | publisher = Dan Ragone | firstdate = 1969 | based = [[New York, NY]] | country = United States | website = [http://www.interviewmagazine.com interviewmagazine.com]}} '''''Interview''''' is an [[United States|American]] [[magazine]] which has the nickname "The Crystal Ball Of Pop". It was founded in late 1969 by artist [[Andy Warhol]]. The magazine features intimate conversations between some of the world's biggest celebrities, artists, musicians, and creative thinkers. Interviews are usually unedited or edited in the eccentric fashion of Warhol's books and ''The Philosophy of Andy Warhol: From A to B and Back Again''. In the early days, complimentary copies of ''Interview'' were often given away to the "in-crowd"; this was the start of the magazine's circulation, which hovers around 230,000. Toward the end of his life, as Warhol withdrew from everyday oversight of his magazine, a more conventional editorial style was introduced under editor [[Bob Colacello]]). However, Warhol continued to act as ambassador for the magazine, distributing issues in the street to passersby and creating ''ad hoc'' signing events on the streets of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. The magazine's format has remained consistent at 60% features and 40% glossy advertising. It has been published since shortly after Warhol's death in 1987 by Brant Publications, Inc. It was helmed for 18 years by Ingrid Sischy, until she and [[Peter Brant]]'s ex-wife Sandra became lovers and left the magazine, selling Ms. Brant's half-ownership stake in the parent company Brant Publications.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ingrid Sischy and Sandra Brant to Helm ‘Vanity Fair’ Abroad|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2008/03/ingrid_sischy_and_sandra_brant.html|accessdate=15 October 2012|newspaper=New York Magazine|date=17 March 2008}}</ref> For a year and a half the magazine was in flux, edited by [[Christopher Bollen]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Management Changes at Interview Magazine|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/20/business/media/20interview.html|accessdate=15 October 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=19 July 2009}}</ref> It "relaunched" under Co-Editorial Directors [[Fabien Baron]] and [[Glenn O'Brien]] in September 2008, with an iconic cover featuring [[Kate Moss]]. Stephen Mooallem and Christopher Bollen serve as the working editor-in-chief and editor-at-large, respectively. The publication's content can be found online and via an [[Application software|app]], Other Edition, available on iTunes. The magazine is currently featured in [[The CW]]'s television series, ''[[The Carrie Diaries (TV Series)|The Carrie Diaries]]'', a prequel to [[HBO|HBO's]] ''[[Sex and the City]]''. The protagonist, played by actress, [[AnnaSophia Robb]], vicariously explores [[New York City]] through the glamorous Fashion Editor of Interview, played by [[Freema Agyeman]]. ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.interviewmagazine.com}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Warhol}} {{Brant Publications}} [[Category:American magazines]] [[Category:Monthly magazines]] [[Category:Publications established in 1969]]
